name: Siem Reap
fun_fact: Fun fact: The Sugar Palm's Chef Kethana won international acclaim for making fish amok 'the old way'â€”steamed, not bakedâ€”and Gordon Ramsay's visit made the restaurant so popular they had to raise prices (but it's still worth it).

hero_dishes.name: Fish Amok at The Sugar Palm
hero_dishes.description: Silky steamed fish curry with lemongrass, turmeric, and coconut milk, wrapped in banana leavesâ€”fragrant, delicate, and authentically Khmer
hero_dishes.origin_story: Chef Kethana insists on the traditional steamed method that takes hours longer than baking. 'If it's not steamed, it's not amok,' she says. Her recipe won Best Amok in Cambodia, even after Gordon Ramsay's endorsement brought international attention
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Sugar Palmâ€”family recipes passed down for generations, now famous worldwide

hero_dishes.name: Prahok K'tis at Mahob Khmer
hero_dishes.description: Fermented fish paste cooked with minced pork and roasted pea eggplants in coconut gravyâ€”pungent, funky, and completely addictive
hero_dishes.origin_story: Prahok is called 'Cambodian cheese' for its intense fermented flavor. Mahob Khmer's version is refined yet authentic, introducing travelers to the ingredient that defines Khmer cooking
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mahob Khmerâ€”where refined meets traditional in modern Cambodian cuisine

hero_dishes.name: Lok Lak at Mahob Khmer
hero_dishes.description: Tender beef stir-fried with black pepper and served over crisp lettuce with lime-pepper dipping sauceâ€”Mahob's version is considered the most tender in Siem Reap
hero_dishes.origin_story: Lok lak evolved from French colonial influences mixed with Khmer flavors. The lime-pepper-salt dip is essential, cutting through the rich beef
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mahob Khmer (most tender version), Chanrey Tree, or The Sugar Palm

hero_dishes.name: Prahok Chamkar's Salted Fish with Crab-Lime Sauce
hero_dishes.description: Grilled fish smothered in a vibrant sauce bursting with whole crabs and fresh limeâ€”a textural adventure of crunchy, tangy, and savory
hero_dishes.origin_story: Prahok Chamkar sits in a lush garden with cabanas and hammocks. The family recipes showcase Cambodian ingredients like nowhere else, with dishes that surprise even seasoned travelers
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Prahok Chamkarâ€”book ahead, especially on weekends, for their garden cabana seating

signature_drinks.name: Fresh Sugarcane Juice
signature_drinks.description: Sweet, grassy juice pressed from fresh sugarcane stalksâ€”served ice-cold with a squeeze of lime
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sold from street carts where you watch the vendor crank the sugarcane through a press. Locals drink it throughout the day to beat the tropical heat, especially after temple exploring

signature_drinks.name: Iced Coffee with Condensed Milk
signature_drinks.description: Thick, sweet Vietnamese-style coffee served over iceâ€”fuel for the hot, humid days
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sipped slowly at morning markets or roadside stalls, often paired with sweet pastries. The French colonial influence lives on in Cambodia's coffee culture

food_culture_notes: Prahok (fermented fish paste) is to Cambodian cooking what fish sauce is to Vietnameseâ€”essential and everywhere
Steamed vs. baked amok is a serious debateâ€”traditional cooks insist on steaming in banana leaves
Pub Street has tourist restaurants, but locals know the best food is at family-run places like Chanrey Tree and Banteay Srey
Siem Reap's food scene preserves Khmer recipes that nearly disappeared during the Khmer Rouge era
